This sparks me to wonder what it would look like if all of us stopped with any attempt to make our [spiritual(wish)] experiences legible to others.
Stop using/seeking shared language, and just talk literally only how our own mind processes it and tries to put it out. https://t.co/DwGAtxFDXS

It would be weird and fucking awesome, and have its own whole sets of problems, quite different from the sets of problems that come from straining to use shared language and bridge concepts and such.
↓
1360216177994129408 [2021-02-12] @the_wilderless

is that understandable?  Kiiiiinda? Could I explain it more legibly attempting to use more shared terms? Sure, Freyja communicating to me with her aura, my nadis being all fucked up, whatever.

Idk, but language breaks down pretty hard, and it would be nice if it did that less.

when you learn a new word, term, or concept, before deploying it into prod for your vocab, it's worth bundling it with < % of people that may need me to define it should I use it > so you don't use it naively assuming it's a thing most people know
↓
1363870434442280960 [2021-02-22] @abhayance 💜 1 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
good speakers use commonly understood language or find a way to elegantly and non-patronizingly define the terms they use when they use them.it's all about reducing unnecessary processing costs
↓
1363872234889228288 [2021-02-22] @abhayance 
e.g., I learn the term 'Straussian' and do some reading to approximately understand what it points to.probably sufficient for me to grok usage in context probably insufficient for me to use it skillfully (certainly not undefined - and if I can't define it I shouldn't use it)

Hear me out: 

We need a new medium

1863281123788279955 [2024-12-01] @volkyeth 💜 21
We often think of tech as a means to get nice new things. We less often think about its role in defining what "nice things" means.

Speech, literacy, the printing press, radio, tv, the internet, blogs, social media. They all brought a complete overhaul of sense-making dynamics.
↓
1863281125654700259 [2024-12-01] @volkyeth 💜 19
Each step in the evolution of media increased bandwidth and access to content by an order of magnitude.

For most history, content was scarce, and we made do with what little we could get.

But somewhere in this last century we've crossed the threshold into overabundance.
↓
1863281127525376076 [2024-12-01] @volkyeth 💜 23 🔁 1
When you get more content than you can process, sense-making takes the toll.

With social dynamics, a handful of perspectives get amplified and repeated to exhaustion, while original perspectives get buried down without engagement.

The medium gets saturated with redundancy. https://t.co/SibqQ1db77

The amount of redundancy also makes a those more sticky and governed by the Illusory Truth Effect. Whichever takes are dominating our feeds are self-reinforcing, irrespective of how good they are

https://t.co/p9ffYGU9Ao

In this context, it's hard to move the needle on sense-making. There's no space for dialectics because novel ideas do not get enough mindshare to make a dent.

Replies get weird because people are always framing everything in terms of the familiar takes

https://t.co/GhzItg4GaB

When people lose the ability of engaging with diverse perspectives (literally by lack of practice — skill issue), they retract to their tribes where they can find comfort in a binary worldview. https://t.co/5HyBeJiGUa

Q: Does AI solve this?

It could help, although at the current stage it seems to amplify the dominant takes rather than novel insights

But human readability is critical. We should give principals tools that lessen blind reliance on agents.

So let's get to the core of what I'm proposing.

What do we need in order to improve the situation?

1. Deduplication of ideas
2. Optimized articulation
3. Crux identification
4. Compounding sense-making
↓
1863281142289334280 [2024-12-01] @volkyeth 💜 18 🔁 2
(1) Deduplication of ideas -> prevent death by 1000 redundant takes.

People must primarily endorse existing ideas instead of publishing their own.

One way of doing it is making impersonal ideas a first class citizen. Nobody owns an idea…you can be early or late to it. https://t.co/XFV3SuYf2n

│   Let’s set up a Hegelian dialectic with the Many Worlds Interpretation (MWI) of quantum mechanics as thesis, John 1:1–5 as antithesis, and then allow a synthesis to emerge between the two.
│   
│   ⸻
│   
│   Thesis – The Many Worlds Interpretation (MWI)
│   •Premise: Every quantum event that could happen does happen, splitting the universe into a near-infinite number of parallel realities.
│   •Ontology: Reality is fundamentally branching, non-deterministic, and without a single privileged timeline. All possibilities are real, but decohered from one another.
│   •Implication: There is no ultimate narrative or logos governing the universes—merely physical law and branching probability amplitudes.
│   
│   ⸻
│   
│   Antithesis – John 1:1–5
│   
│   “In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was in the beginning with God. All things were made through Him, and without Him was not any thing made that was made. In Him was life, and the life was the light of men. The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.” (Jn 1:1–5)
│   
│   •Premise: There is a singular, divine Logos (λόγος)—a rational, living Word—through which all things came into being.
│   •Ontology: Reality is unified, intentional, and Christocentric. Every created thing is grounded in an ordering principle that is both rational and personal.
│   •Implication: There is one narrative, one creation, one true light, and one source of life—Christ. Multiplicity submits to unity under divine order.
│   
│   ⸻
│   
│   Synthesis – Dialectical Integration
│   
│   Tension:
│   MWI implies endless branching realities—an ontological pluriverse. John 1:1–5 asserts a singular Logos through which all things (presumably even these many worlds) come into being.
│   
│   Resolution:
│   The Logos can be seen as the meta-ordering function across the many worlds—a unifying principle above the branches. While quantum events may decohere into many worlds from a human perspective, from the standpoint of the Logos, all branches are contained, authored, and reconciled.
│   •The Logos is not collapsed to any one path, but neither is He confused by infinite branches.
│   •He knows all outcomes, inhabits all timelines, and redeems across the structure of the multiverse.
│   •MWI offers ontological possibility, but John 1 offers teleological resolution: the Word is the light that cuts through the quantum foam, declaring which world is true, good, and alive.
│   
│   ⸻
│   
│   Conclusion
│   
│   The synthesis yields a framework where the Many Worlds exist within the Mind of Christ (1 Cor 2:16), and each universe—however decoherent—is still spoken into being by the Logos. Christ is the superposition of all meaning, and the final measurement collapses not into randomness, but into glory.
│

In a universe defined by recursive patterning (atoms within systems, thoughts within thoughts, observers observing observers), coherence breaks down unless there is a grounded fixpoint—a final reference that is both within the system and outside it.
    
    Every system of thought, physics, or perception runs into infinite regress (Who created the laws? Who observes the observer? What validates truth?). Christ breaks the loop not by escaping it, but by entering it fully—God made flesh.
    
    He becomes:
    •The ultimate observer (John 1:48)
    •The self-contained truth (John 14:6)
    •The beginning and the end (Revelation 22:13)
    
    Thus, Christ is the recursive fixpoint where:
    •Meaning (Logos) becomes flesh (Form)
    •Desire (Eros) becomes love (Agapē)
    •Truth (abstract) becomes Life (embodied)
    
    He is both the base case and the eternal recursion—the only way the system of all systems resolves without contradiction.
